September 4, 1781 |established_title2 = Incorporated |established_date2 = April 4, 1850 |footnotes = }} '''Los Angeles''' ({{IPAc-en|audio=En-us-los-angeles.ogg|l|É|s|_|Ë|Ã¦|n|dÊ|É|l|É|s}} {{respell|loss|AN|jÉ-lÉs}}; {{IPA-es|los ËaÅxeles|lang}}), with a population at the [[2010 United States Census]] of 3,792,621, is the [[List of cities in California (by population)|most populous city]] in [[California]], [[USA]] and the [[List of United States cities by population|second most populous]] in the [[United States]], after [[New York City]].{{cite web | url = http://search.census.gov/search?q=cache:b2N7EEjvBBcJ:2010.census.gov/news/xls/cb11cn68_ca_2010redistr.xls+2010+los+angeles+city+population&output=xml_no_dtd&ie=UTF-8&client=2010prod&proxystylesheet=2010prod&site=2010&access=p&oe=UTF-8| title = The Most Populous Counties and Incorporated Places in 2010 in California | publisher = U.S. Census Bureau | year = 2010 | accessdate = 28 September 2011}}{{cite web | url = http://2010.census.gov/news/releases/operations/cb11-cn124.html | title = U.S. Census Bureau Releases Data on Population Distribution and Change in the U.S. Based on Analysis of 2010 Census Results | date = 24 March 2010 | publisher = U.S. Census Bureau | accessdate = September 28, 2011}} It has an area of {{convert|468.67|sqmi|km2|1}}, and is located in [[Southern California]]. Often known by its initials '''LA''', the city is the focal point of the larger [[Los Angeles metropolitan area|Los Angeles-Long Beach-Santa Ana metropolitan statistical area]], which contains 12,828,837 people as of 2010, and is one of the [[List of metropolitan areas by population|most populous metropolitan areas]] in the world{{cite web|url=http://www.worldatlas.com/citypops.htm |title=City Populations â World City Population, Biggest Largest Cities in the World |publisher=Worldatlas.com |accessdate=28 September 2011}} and the second largest in the United States.{{cite web | url=http://factfinder2.census.gov/faces/tableservices/jsf/pages/productview.xhtml?pid=DEC_10_NSRD_GCTPL2.US24PR&prodType=table| title = Population and Housing Occupancy Status: 2010 - United States -- Metropolitan Statistical Area | publisher = U.S. Census Bureau | accessdate = 28 September 2011}} Los Angeles is also the [[county seat|seat]] of [[Los Angeles County, California|Los Angeles County]], the most populated and one of the most ethnically diverse [[county (US)|counties]]{{cite news|author=Les Christie |url=http://money.cnn.com/2007/08/08/real_estate/most_diverse_counties/index.htm |title=The most ethnically diverse counties in the United States |publisher=CNN |date=9 August 2007|accessdate=28 September 2011}} in the United States, while according to [[CNBC.com]], the Los Angeles area itself is the most diverse metropolitan area in the United States.{{cite web|url=http://www.cnbc.com/id/43066296/The_Top_10_Most_Diverse_Cities_in_America?slide=11 |title=The Top 10 Most Diverse Cities in America |publisher=cnbc.com |accessdate=28 September 2011}} The city's inhabitants are referred to as ""[[Angelenos]]".{{cite web |url=http://www.thefreedictionary.com/Angeleno |title=Angeleno |publisher=The Free Dictionary |accessdate=28 September 2011}} Los Angeles was founded on September 4, 1781, by Spanish governor [[Felipe de Neve]].{{cite book|last=Barrows|first=H.D.|title=Historical Society of Southern California Quarterly|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=JMg1AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA151|accessdate=28 September 2011|year=1899|page=151ff|chapter=Felepe de Neve|volume=4}} It became a part of [[Mexico]] in 1821 following the [[Mexican War of Independence]].{{cite book|last=Estrada|first=William D.|title=The Los Angeles Plaza: sacred and contested space|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=eJu4Wau5G5UC&pg=PA43|accessdate=28 September 2011|date=15 April 2008|publisher=University of Texas Press|isbn=978-0-292-71755-8|page=43}} In 1848, at the end of the [[MexicanâAmerican War]], Los Angeles and the rest of California were purchased as part of the [[Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo]], thereby becoming part of the United States.{{cite book|last=Spencer|first=Jesse Ames|title=History of the United States: From the earliest period to the administration of James Buchanan|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=4k5XAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA453|accessdate= 28 September 2011|year=1866|publisher=Johnson, Fry and company|page=453}} Los Angeles was [[Municipal corporation|incorporated]] as a municipality on April 4, 1850, five months before California achieved [[U.S. state|statehood]].{{cite web | url = http://ceo.lacounty.gov/forms/09-10%20cities%20alpha.pdf | title = Cities Within the County of Los Angeles | publisher = Los Angeles County | accessdate = 28 September 2011}} Nicknamed the ''City of Angels'', Los Angeles is a [[Global city|world center]] of business, international trade, entertainment, culture, media, fashion, science, technology, and education. It is home to renowned institutions covering a broad range of professional and cultural fields and is one of the most substantial economic engines within the United States. Los Angeles has been ranked the third richest city and fifth most powerful and influential city in the world, behind only New York City in the United States.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/BUSINESS/04/10/cities.dominate.world/index.html?thisSpeed=30000 |title=Revealed: Cities that rule the world |publisher=CNN |date=10 April 2010 |accessdate=20 October 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.foreignpolicy.com/node/373401 |title=The Global Cities Index 2010 |publisher=Foreign Policy |year=2010 |accessdate=20 October 2011}} The Los Angeles [[combined statistical area]] (CSA) has a [[gross metropolitan product]] (GMP) of $831 billion (as of 2008), making it the [[List of cities by GDP|third largest economic center in the world]], after the [[Greater Tokyo]] and [[New York metropolitan area|New York]] metropolitan areas.{{cite web|url=http://www.citymayors.com/statistics/richest-cities-2005.html |publisher=citymayors.com|title=The 150 richest cities in the world by GDP in 2005|date= 11 March 2007|accessdate=20 October 2011}} The list fails to include Taipei. As the home base of [[Hollywood]], it is known as the "Entertainment Capital of the World", leading the world in the creation of television production, video games, and recorded music. The importance of the entertainment business to the city has led many celebrities to call Los Angeles and its surrounding suburbs home. Los Angeles hosted the [[1932 Summer Olympics|1932]] and [[1984 Summer Olympics]]. Los Angeles is also home to renowned universities such as the [[University of Southern California]] and the [[University of California, Los Angeles]]. Los Angeles enjoys a [[Mediterranean climate]], with an average of 35 days with measurable precipitation annually. ==History== {{Quote box |width=20em |align=left |bgcolor=#B0C4DE |title=Historical Affiliations |fontsize=90% |quote=[[Spanish Empire]] 1781-1821
[[First Mexican Empire]] 1821-1823
[[United Mexican States]] 1823-1848 }} {{Main|History of Los Angeles}} [[Image:LosAngeles-Plaza-1869.jpg|thumb|240px|The old city plaza, 1869]] [[Image:LosAngelesCityHall1931.JPG|thumb|240px|[[Los Angeles City Hall]], shown here in 1931, was built in 1928 and was the tallest structure in the city until 1964, when height restrictions were removed.]] The Los Angeles coastal area was first settled by the [[Tongva people|Tongva]] (or GabrieleÃ±os) and [[Chumash people|Chumash]] Native American tribes thousands of years ago. [[Juan RodrÃ­guez Cabrillo]], a Portuguese-born explorer, claimed the area of southern California for the [[Spanish Empire]] in 1542.{{cite book|last=Willard|first=Charles Dwight|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=o0cOAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA21 |title=The Herald's History of Los Angeles|location=Los Angeles|publisher=Kingsley-Barnes & Neuner|year=1901|pages=21â24|accessdate=29 September 2011}} [[Gaspar de PortolÃ ]] and [[Franciscan]] missionary [[Juan CrespÃ­]], reached the present site of Los Angeles on August 2, 1769.{{cite web|title=Father Crespi in Los Angeles|url=http://www.usc.edu/libraries/archives/la/historic/crespi.html|work=Los Angeles: Past, Present and Future|publisher = University of Southern California | accessdate = 29 September 2011}} In 1771, Franciscan friar [[JunÃ­pero Serra]] directed the building of the [[Mission San Gabriel ArcÃ¡ngel|Mission San Gabriel Arcangel]], the first mission in the area.{{cite book|last1=Leffingwell|first1=Randy|last2=Worden|first2=Alastair|title=California missions and presidios|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=zFn57UJ1mJIC&pg=PA43|accessdate=30 September 2011|date=4 November 2005|publisher=Voyageur Press|isbn=978-0-89658-492-1|pages=43â44}} On September 4, 1781, a group of forty-four settlers known as "[[Los Pobladores]]" founded the town named ''El Pueblo de [[Blessed Virgin Mary (Roman Catholic)|Nuestra SeÃ±ora la Reina de los Ãngeles]] del [[Los Angeles River#History|RÃ­o de PorciÃºncula]]'' (The Town of [[Blessed Virgin Mary (Roman Catholic)|Our Lady the Queen of the Angels]] of the PorciÃºncula River).{{cite book|last=Sullivan|first=Noelle|title=It Happened in Southern California: Remarkable Events That Shaped History|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=bwRrshiH0oUC&pg=PA7|accessdate=29 September 2011|edition=2nd|date=8 December 2009|publisher=Globe Pequot|isbn=978-0-7627-5423-6|pages=7â9}} Two-thirds of the settlers were [[mestizo]] or [[mulatto]] with African, Amerindian, and European ancestry.{{cite book|last1=Mulroy|first1=Kevin|last2=Taylor|first2=Quintard|author3=Autry Museum of Western Heritage|title=Seeking El Dorado: African Americans in California|url=http://books.google.com/?id=2eH35EuLuUsC|accessdate=30 September 2011|date=March 2001|publisher=University of Washington Press|isbn=978-0-295-98082-9|page=79|chapter=The Early African Heritage in California (Forbes, Jack D.)}} The settlement remained a small ranch town for decades, but by 1820 the population had increased to about 650 residents.{{cite book|last=Guinn|first=James Miller|title=Historical and biographical record of southern California: containing a history of southern California from its earliest settlement to the opening year of the twentieth century|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=KyFPAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=30 September 2011|year=1902|publisher=Chapman pub. co.|page=63}} Today, the pueblo is commemorated in the historic district of [[Los Angeles Plaza Historic District|Los Angeles Pueblo Plaza]] and [[Olvera Street]], the oldest part of Los Angeles.{{cite book|last=Estrada|first=William D.|title=Los Angeles's Olvera Street|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=NzlO8C5-Q88C|accessdate=30 September 2011|year = 2006|publisher=Arcadia Publishing|isbn=978-0-7385-3105-2}} New Spain achieved its independence from the Spanish Empire in 1821, and the pueblo continued as a part of Mexico. During Mexican rule, Governor [[PÃ­o Pico]], made Los Angeles [[Alta California]]'s regional capital. Mexican rule ended during the [[MexicanâAmerican War]]: Americans took control from the [[Californios]] after a series of battles, culminating with the signing of the [[Treaty of Cahuenga]] on January 13, 1847.{{cite book|last=Guinn|first=James Miller|title=Historical and biographical record of southern California: containing a history of southern California from its earliest settlement to the opening year of the twentieth century|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=KyFPAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=30 September 2011|year=1902|publisher=Chapman pub. co.|page=50}} [[History of rail transportation in California|Railroads arrived]] with the completion of the [[Southern Pacific Railroad|Southern Pacific]] line to Los Angeles in 1876.{{cite book|last=Mulholland|first=Catherine|title=William Mulholland and the Rise of Los Angeles|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=iP575do7D48C|accessdate=30 September 2011|year=2002|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-23466-6|page=15}} Oil was discovered in 1892, and by 1923, the discoveries had helped California become the country's largest oil producer, accounting for about one-quarter of the world's petroleum output.{{cite book|last=Kipen|first=David|title=Los Angeles in the 1930s: The WPA Guide to the City of Angels|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=aezmS52IavcC&pg=PA45|accessdate=30 September 2011|year=2011|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-26883-8|pages=45â46}} By 1900, the population had grown to more than 102,000 people,{{cite web|url=http://www.census.gov/population/documentation/twps0027/tab13.txt |title=Population of the 100 Largest Urban Places: 1900 |accessdate=30 September 2011|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080206033006/http://www.census.gov/population/documentation/twps0027/tab13.txt |archivedate = 6 February 2008|publisher= U.S. Census}} putting pressure on the city's [[water supply]].{{cite web|url=http://www.american.edu/TED/mono.htm |title=The Los roches Aqueduct and the Owens and Mono Lakes (MONO Case) |publisher=American.edu |accessdate=30 September 2011}} The completion of the [[Los Angeles Aqueduct]] in 1913, under the supervision of [[William Mulholland]], assured the continued growth of the city.{{cite book|last=Reisner|first=Marc|authorlink=Marc Reisner|title=Cadillac desert: the American West and its disappearing water|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=Akn6rUgR_eEC|accessdate=30 September 2011|year=1993|publisher=Penguin|isbn=978-0-14-017824-1|page=86}} In 1910, not only had the city of Los Angeles just annexed Hollywood, but there were already at least ten movie companies operating in the city. By 1921, more than 80% of the world's film industry was concentrated in L.A.{{cite book|last=Buntin|first=John|title=L.A. Noir: The Struggle for the Soul of America's Most Seductive City|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=y6ZlIkYXjiMC&pg=PA18|accessdate=30 September 2011|date=6 April 2010|publisher=Random House Digital, Inc.|isbn=978-0-307-35208-8|page=18}} The money generated by the industry kept the city relatively insulated from much of the economic pain suffered by the rest of the country during the [[Great Depression in the United States|Great Depression]].{{cite book|last1=Young|first1=William H.|last2=Young|first2=Nancy K.|title=The Great Depression in America: a cultural encyclopedia|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=QYYMqXUyjnUC&pg=PA21|accessdate=30 September 2011|date=March 2007|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-313-33521-1|page=21}} By 1930, the population surpassed one million.{{cite web|url=http://www.census.gov/population/documentation/twps0027/tab16.txt |title=Population of the 100 Largest Urban Places: 1930 |accessdate=1 October 2011 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080205005417/http://www.census.gov/population/documentation/twps0027/tab16.txt |archivedate = 6 February 2008|publisher=U.S. Census|unused_data=publisher U.S. Census}} In 1932, the city hosted the [[1932 Summer Olympics|Summer Olympics]]. [[File:Olympic Torch Tower of the Los Angeles Coliseum.jpg|thumb|240px|The [[Los Angeles Coliseum]] hosted the Olympic Games in 1932 and 1984. ]] After [[WWII|the second world war]], the city grew more rapidly than ever, [[urban sprawl|sprawling]] into the [[San Fernando Valley]].{{cite book|last=Bruegmann|first=Robert|authorlink=Robert Bruegmann|title=Sprawl: A Compact History|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=HFjLm2BauZ8C|accessdate=1 October 2011|date=1 November 2006|publisher=University of Chicago Press|isbn=978-0-226-07691-1|page=133}} In 1969, Los Angeles became one of the birthplaces of the Internet, as the first [[ARPANET]] transmission was sent from the [[University of California, Los Angeles]] (UCLA) to [[SRI International|SRI]] in [[Menlo Park, California|Menlo Park]].{{cite book|last1=Hafner|first1=Katie|authorlink1=Katie Hafner|last2=Lyon|first2=Matthew|title=Where Wizards Stay Up Late: The Origins Of The Internet|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=RLKxSvCBQZcC|accessdate=1 October 2011|date=1 August 1999|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=978-0-684-87216-2|page=153}} In 1984, the city hosted the Summer Olympic Games [[1984 Summer Olympics|for the second time]]. Despite being [[1984 Summer Olympics boycott|boycotted by 14 Communist countries]], the 1984 Olympics became vastly more financially successful than any previous,{{cite web | url = http://articles.latimes.com/2004/jun/30/local/me-rood30 | title = Rodney W. Rood, 88; Played Key Role in 1984 Olympics, Built Support for Metro Rail | author = Elaine Woo | date = 30 June 2004 | publisher = Los Angeles Times | accessdate = 1 October 2011}} and only the second Olympics to turn a profit until then â the other, according to an analysis of contemporary newspaper reports, being the 1932 Summer Olympics, also held in Los Angeles.{{cite journal | last = Zarnowski | first = C. Frank | year = 1992 | month = Summer | title = A Look at Olympic Costs | journal = Citius, Altius, Fortius | volume = 1 | issue = 1 | pages = 16â32 | url = http://www.aafla.org/SportsLibrary/JOH/JOHv1n1/JOHv1n1f.pdf | accessdate = 1 October 2011}} Racial tensions erupted on April 29, 1992, with the acquittal by a [[Simi Valley]] jury of the police officers captured on videotape beating [[Rodney King]], culminating in [[Los Angeles riots of 1992|large-scale riots]].{{cite book|last1=Rucker|first1=Walter C.|last2=Upton|first2=James N.|last3=Hughey|first3=Matthew W.|title=Encyclopedia of American race riots|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=mQcrpqn0124C&pg=PA376|accessdate=1 October 2011|year=2007|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-313-33301-9|pages=376â85|chapter=Los Angeles (California) Riots of 1992}} In 1994, the 6.7 [[Northridge earthquake]] shook the city, causing $12.5 billion in damage and 72 deaths.{{cite news|last=Reich|first=Kenneth|title=Study Raises Northridge Quake Death Toll to 72|work=Los Angeles Times|date=20 December 1995|page=B1|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1995-12-20/news/mn-16032_1_quake-death-toll|accessdate= 1 October 2011}} The century ended with the [[Rampart scandal]], one of the most extensive cases of police misconduct in American history.{{cite web | url = http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/lapd/scandal/cron.html | publisher = [[PBS]] | title = Rampart Scandal Timeline | accessdate = 1 October 2011}} Voters defeated efforts by the San Fernando Valley and Hollywood to secede from the city in 2002.{{cite web|url=http://www.laalmanac.com/election/el22.htm |title=City of Los Angeles Secession Votes â 2002 |publisher=Laalmanac.com |accessdate=2 October 2011}} ==Geography== {{See also|Los Angeles Basin|San Fernando Valley|Greater Los Angeles area|Los Angeles County, California}} ===Topography=== [[File:Los Angeles Basin JPLLandsat.jpg|thumb|240px|The [[Los Angeles Basin]]]] Los Angeles is irregularly shaped and covers a total area of {{convert|502.7|sqmi|km2|0|sp=us}}, comprising {{convert|468.7|sqmi|km2}} of land and {{convert|34.0|sqmi|km2}} of water. The city extends for {{convert|44|mi|km}} longitudinally and for {{convert|29|mi|km}} latitudinally. The perimeter of the city is {{convert|342|mi|km}}. Los Angeles is both flat and hilly. The highest point in the city is {{convert|5074|ft|m|abbr=on}} [[Mount Lukens]],{{cite web|url=http://egsc.usgs.gov/isb/pubs/booklets/elvadist/elvadist.html#50| title=Elevations of the 50 Largest Cities (by population, 1980 Census) â USGS| publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]]| accessdate=3 October 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://angeles.sierraclub.org/hps/guides/09e.htm| title=Mount Lukens - Sierra Club - Hundred Peak Section | publisher=[[Sierra Club]] Angeles Chapter| accessdate=3 October 2011}} located at the northeastern end of the San Fernando Valley. The eastern end of the [[Santa Monica Mountains]] stretches from Downtown to the Pacific Ocean and separates the Los Angeles Basin from the San Fernando Valley. Other hilly parts of Los Angeles include the [[Mt. Washington, Los Angeles|Mt. Washington]] area north of Downtown, eastern parts such as [[Boyle Heights]], the [[Crenshaw, Los Angeles|Crenshaw district]] around the [[Baldwin Hills, Los Angeles|Baldwin Hills]], and the [[San Pedro, Los Angeles|San Pedro]] district. [[Image:Los Angeles River Anas platyrhynchos crop.jpg|thumb|240px|Mallards on the [[Los Angeles River]]]]The [[Los Angeles River]], which is largely seasonal, is the primary drainage channel. It was straightened and lined in 51 miles of concrete by the [[Army Corps of Engineers]] to act as a flood control channel.{{cite book|last=Gumprecht|first=Blake|title=The Los Angeles River: Its Life, Death, and Possible Rebirth|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=2ftBJpp7aIoC|accessdate=3 October 2011|date=March 2001|publisher=JHU Press|isbn=978-0-8018-6642-5|page=173}} The river begins in the [[Canoga Park, Los Angeles|Canoga Park]] district of the city, flows east from the San Fernando Valley along the north edge of the Santa Monica Mountains, and turns south through the city center, flowing to its mouth in the Port of [[Long Beach, California|Long Beach]] at the Pacific Ocean. The smaller [[Ballona Creek]] flows into the [[Santa Monica Bay]] at [[Playa del Rey, Los Angeles|Playa del Rey]]. [[File:Macarthur Park.jpg|thumb|230px|[[MacArthur Park]]]] The Los Angeles area is rich in native plant species due in part to a diversity in habitats, including beaches, [[wetland]]s, and mountains. The most prevalent botanical environment is [[coastal sage scrub]],{{cite book|last=Miller|first=George Oxford|title=Landscaping with Native Plants of Southern California|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=RjbPQ6ZOgzMC&pg=PA15|accessdate=6 October 2011|date=15 January 2008|publisher=Voyageur Press|isbn=978-0-7603-2967-2|page=15}} which covers the hillsides in combustible [[California chaparral and woodlands|chaparral]]. Native plants include: [[California poppy]], [[matilija poppy]], [[Heteromeles|toyon]], [[Coast Live Oak]], and [[Leymus condensatus|Giant Wildrye]]. Many of these native species, such as the [[Helianthus nuttallii|Los Angeles sunflower]], have become so rare as to be considered endangered. Though it is not native to the area, the official tree of Los Angeles is the Coral Tree (''[[Erythrina caffra]]''){{cite book|author=National Research Council (U.S.). Advisory Committee on Technology Innovation|title=Tropical legumes: resources for the future : report of an ad hoc panel of the Advisory Committee on Technology Innovation, Board on Science and Technology for International Development, Commission on International Relations, National Research Council|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=MkArAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA258|accessdate=6 October 2011|year=1979|publisher=National Academies|page=258|id=NAP:14318}} and the official flower of Los Angeles is the Bird of Paradise (''[[Strelitzia reginae]]'').{{cite book|title=Los Angeles Magazine|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=-10EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA62|accessdate=6 October 2011|date=April 2003|publisher=Emmis Communications|page=62|chapter=Flower|issn=15229149}} [[Washingtonia robusta|Mexican Fan Palm]]s, [[Washingtonia filifera|California Fan Palm]]s, and [[Phoenix canariensis|Canary Island Palm]]s can be seen throughout the Los Angeles area, despite the latter being non-indigenous to Southern California. ===Geology=== Los Angeles is subject to earthquakes due to its location on the [[Pacific Ring of Fire]]. The geologic instability has produced numerous [[fault (geology)|faults]], which cause approximately 10,000 earthquakes annually.{{cite web|url=http://earthquake.usgs.gov/learn/facts.php |title=Earthquake Facts |publisher=Earthquake.usgs.gov |accessdate=3 October 2011}} One of the major faults is the [[San Andreas Fault]]. Located at the boundary between the [[Pacific Plate]] and the [[North American Plate]], it is predicted to be the source of Southern California's next big earthquake.{{cite web|url=http://www.physorg.com/news70114196.html |title=San Andreas Fault Set for the Big One |publisher=Physorg.com |date=21 June 2006 |accessdate=3 October 2011}} Major earthquakes to have hit the Los Angeles area include the 1994 [[Northridge earthquake]], the 1987 [[Whittier Narrows earthquake]], the [[1971 San Fernando earthquake]] near [[Sylmar, Los Angeles|Sylmar]], and the [[1933 Long Beach earthquake]]. Nevertheless, all but a few quakes are of low intensity and are not felt. The Los Angeles basin and metropolitan area are also at risk from [[blind thrust earthquake]]s.{{cite journal | url = https://www.sciencemag.org/content/283/5407/1516.abstract?ck=nck | journal = Science | title = An Elusive Blind-Thrust Fault Beneath Metropolitan Los Angeles | date = 5 March 1999 | volume = 283 | pages = 1516â1518 | last1 = Shaw | first1 = John H. | last2 = Shearer | first2 = Peter M. | accessdate = 3 October 2011 | issue = 5407 | doi = 10.1126/science.283.5407.1516 | pmid = 10066170}} Parts of the city are also vulnerable to [[tsunami]]s; harbor areas were damaged by waves from the [[1960 Valdivia earthquake|Valdivia earthquake]] in 1960.{{cite web| url=http://wcatwc.arh.noaa.gov/web_tsus/19600522/damage.htm|title=May 22, 1960 South Central Chile Tsunami Damage along the Alaska, British Columbia, Washington, Oregon, and California coasts|accessdate=3 October 2011| work=May 22, 1960 South Central Chile Tsunami Coverage|publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]]}} ===Climate=== {{Main|Climate of the Los Angeles Basin}} [[Image:LA Echo.JPG|thumb|240px|[[Echo Park, Los Angeles|Echo Park]] as seen with [[Arecaceae|palm trees]]]] Los Angeles has a [[Subtropical]]-[[Mediterranean climate]] ([[KÃ¶ppen climate classification]] ''Csb'' on the coast, ''Csa'' inland), and receives just enough annual precipitation to avoid KÃ¶ppen's ''BSh'' ([[semi-arid climate]]) classification. Los Angeles enjoys plenty of sunshine throughout the year, with an average of only 35 days with measurable precipitation annually.{{cite web|url=http://www.weatherbase.com/weather/weather.php3?s=159227&refer=| title=Weatherbase: Historical Weather for Los Angeles, California, United States of America| publisher=Weatherbase.com| accessdate=20 October 2011}} The average annual temperature in downtown is {{convert|66|Â°F|Â°C|abbr=on}}: {{convert|75|Â°F|Â°C|abbr=on}} during the day and {{convert|57|Â°F|Â°C|abbr=on}} at night. In the coldest month, January, the temperature typically ranges from {{convert|59|to|73|F|C}} during the day and {{convert|45|to|55|F|C}} at night. In the warmest month â August â the temperature typically ranges from {{convert|79|to|90|F|C}} during the day and around {{convert|64|Â°F|Â°C|abbr=on}} at night. Temperatures exceed {{convert|90|F|C|abbr=on}} on a dozen or so days in the year, from one day a month in April, May, June and November to three days a month in July, August, October and to five days in September. Temperatures are subject to substantial daily swings; in inland areas the difference between the average daily low and the average daily high is over 30 Â°F (17 Â°C).{{cite web | url = http://cdo.ncdc.noaa.gov/climatenormals/clim20/ca/041484.pdf | title = Climatography of the United States No. 20 (1971â2000) â Canoga Park Pierce Collg, CA | format=PDF | year=2004 | publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] | accessdate=5 October 2011}} The average annual temperature of the sea is {{convert|63|Â°F|Â°C|abbr=on}}, from {{convert|58|Â°F|Â°C|abbr=on}} in January to {{convert|68|Â°F|Â°C|abbr=on}} in August.{{cite web|url=http://www.beachcalifornia.com/beach/california-ocean-temperature.html|title=Pacific Ocean Temperatures on California Coast|publisher=beachcalifornia.com|accessdate=5 October 2011}} Hours of sunshine total more than 3,000 per year, from an average of 7 hours of sunshine per day in December to an average of 12 in July.{{cite web|url=http://www.weather2travel.com/climate-guides/united-states/california/los-angeles-ca.php|title=Los Angeles Climate Guide|publisher=weather2travel.com|accessdate=5 October 2011}} The Los Angeles area is also subject to phenomena typical of a [[microclimate]], causing extreme variations in temperature in close physical proximity to each other. For instance, the average July maximum temperature at the [[Santa Monica Pier]] is {{convert|75|F|C}} whereas it is {{convert|95|F|C}} in Canoga Park.{{cite web | url = http://www.wrcc.dri.edu/narratives/CALIFORNIA.htm | title = Climate of California | publisher = Western Regional Climate Center|accessdate = 6 October 2011}} The city, like much of the southern California coast, is subject to a late spring/early summer weather phenomenon called "[[June Gloom]]." This involves overcast or foggy skies in the morning which yield to sun by early afternoon.{{cite book|last=Poole|first=Matthew R.|title=Frommer's Los Angeles 2011|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=HAPWv2OkeXUC&pg=PA22|accessdate=5 October 2011|date=22 September 2010|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-0-470-62619-1|page=22}} Downtown Los Angeles averages {{convert|15.14|in|mm|1}} of precipitation annually, which mainly occurs during the winter and spring (November through April) with generally moderate rain showers, but often as heavy rainfall and thunderstorms during winter storms. The coast gets slightly less rainfall, while the mountains get slightly more. However the San Fernando Valley Region of Los Angeles can get between {{convert|16|and|20|in|mm}} of rain per year. Years of average rainfall are rare; the usual pattern is [[bimodal]], with a short string of dry years (perhaps {{convert|7|â|8|in|mm|disp=s}}) followed by one or two wet years that make up the average. Snowfall is extremely rare in the city basin, but the mountains within city limits typically receive snowfall every winter. The greatest snowfall recorded in downtown Los Angeles was {{convert|2|in|cm|0}} in 1932.{{cite book|last1=Burt|first1=Christopher C.|last2=Stroud|first2=Mark|title=Extreme weather: a guide & record book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=SV229set7RIC&pg=PA100|accessdate=5 October 2011|date=26 June 2007|publisher=W. W. Norton & Company|isbn=978-0-393-33015-1|page=100}} The highest recorded temperature in downtown Los Angeles is {{convert|113|F|C}} on September 27, 2010{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/sep/27/local/la-me-hottest-ever-20100928|title=L.A.'s hottest day ever|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=5 October 2011|first1=Bob|last1=Pool|first2=Rong-Gong|last2=Lin II}} and the lowest recorded temperature is {{convert|24|F|C}} on December 22, 1944. {{-}} {{Los Angeles weatherbox}} {{Weather box |collapsed =
